title: Sperm competition and maternal effects differentially influence testis and sperm size in Callosobruchus maculatus
abstract:
The evolutionary factors affecting testis size are well documented, with sperm\ud
competition being of major importance. However, the factors affecting sperm\ud
length are not well understood; there are no clear theoretical predictions and\ud
the empirical evidence is inconsistent. Recently, maternal effects have been\ud
implicated in sperm length variation, a finding that may offer insights into its\ud
evolution. We investigated potential proximate and microevolutionary factors\ud
influencing testis and sperm size in the bruchid beetle Callosobruchus maculatus\ud
using a combined approach of an artificial evolution experiment over 90\ud
generations and an environmental effects study. We found that while\ud
polyandry seems to select for larger testes, it had no detectable effect on\ud
sperm length. Furthermore, population density, a proximate indicator of\ud
sperm competition risk, was not significantly associated with sperm length or\ud
testis size variation. However, there were strong maternal effects influencing sperm length
